Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. OBSERVED SYMPTOMS\\nThe following symptoms/alerts were detected by an anomaly detector, ordered by time. Metric and trace alerts are reported based on the first observed anomalous value, not the full duration of the abnormal behavior. For example, if a metric remains abnormal for several seconds, only the initial timestamp is included.\\n- 2022-03-20 08:40:00.000 | METRIC | cartservice | grpc-mrt | up\\n- 2022-03-20 08:40:00.000 | METRIC | checkoutservice | grpc-mrt | up\\n- 2022-03-20 08:40:00.000 | METRIC | frontend | http-mrt | up\\n- 2022-03-20 08:41:00.000 | METRIC | cartservice-1 | container_network_receive_MB.eth0 | up\\n- 2022-03-20 08:42:00.000 | METRIC | node-5 | system.cpu.pct_usage | up\\n- 2022-03-20 08:42:51.000 | LOG | redis-cart-0 | 08:42:51.000: `Background saving started by pid 1569`\\n- 2022-03-20 08:42:51.000 | LOG | redis-cart-0 | 08:42:51.000: `100 changes in 300 seconds. Saving...`\\n- 2022-03-20 08:42:52.000 | LOG | redis-cart-0 | 08:42:52.000: `DB saved on disk`\\n- 2022-03-20 08:42:52.000 | LOG | redis-cart-0 | 08:42:52.000: `Background saving terminated with success`\\n- 2022-03-20 08:42:52.000 | LOG | redis-cart-0 | 08:42:52.000: `RDB: 0 MB of memory used by copy-on-write`\\n- 2022-03-20 08:44:00.000 | METRIC | paymentservice-1 | container_network_receive_packets.eth0 | up\\n- 2022-03-20 08:45:00.000 | METRIC | currencyservice-1 | container_network_receive_MB.eth0 | up\\n- 2022-03-20 08:45:00.000 | METRIC | emailservice-1 | container_network_receive_MB.eth0 | up\\n- 2022-03-20 08:46:00.000 | METRIC | adservice2-0 | container_network_receive_MB.eth0 | up\\n- 2022-03-20 08:47:00.000 | METRIC | node-1 | system.io.r_s | up\\n- 2022-03-20 08:48:00.000 | METRIC | frontend-1 | container_fs_reads./dev/vda | up\\n- 2022-03-20 08:48:00.000 | METRIC | frontend2-0 | container_network_receive_MB.eth0 | up\\n- 2022-03-20 08:48:00.000 | METRIC | node-5 | system.io.w_s | up\\n\\n## TASK\\nUse the knowledge graph and the observed alerts to identify the **three most likely root cause faults** that could explain the symptoms.\\n\\nEach fault:\\n- Must be localized to a single system component (node in the graph) of type `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- Must be restricted to the fault types listed in the INSTRUCTIONS section below\\n- Should include a plausible propagation path through the system that justifies how the fault led to the observed symptoms. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Ensure your reasoning is traceable and grounded in the knowledge graph.\", \"type\": \"human\", \"id\": \"8028d087-8ecb-4f70-96aa-0bcf40b8e7a8\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"AIMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"<think>\\nOkay, so I'm trying to figure out the root cause of the symptoms observed in this cloud-based system. Let's see, the system has multiple services and components connected through a knowledge graph, and there are several alerts that have been triggered. I need to identify the three most likely root causes.\\n\\nFirst, I'll start by looking at the observed symptoms. The alerts are a mix of metric, log, and possibly trace alerts. The metric alerts include things like container network receive metrics spiking up, node CPU usage, and disk I/O. Then there are the logs from redis-cart-0 about background saving and some metrics about network receive packets and MB.\\n\\nHmm, the logs from redis-cart-0 show that a background save started, which is a normal operation for Redis, but it's something to note. The fact that it mentions 100 changes in 300 seconds and then successfully saved the DB suggests that Redis is handling its persistence correctly. But maybe the saving process is causing some resource issues?\\n\\nLooking at the metric alerts, I see that node-5 has high CPU usage at 08:42:00, and later high I/O writes. There are also multiple container network receive metrics spiking for services like cartservice-1, paymentservice-1, currencyservice-1, etc. This might indicate network congestion or increased traffic.\\n\\nNow, considering the knowledge graph, I see that many services are hosted on node-6, but some are on node-5. For example, cartservice2-0, checkoutservice-2, shippingservice-2, and adservice-2 are all on node-5. So if node-5 is experiencing high CPU and I/O, that could affect these services.\\n\\nLet me think about possible faults. One possibility is a node-level CPU load issue on node-5. The high CPU usage could be causing the services hosted there to perform poorly, leading to network metrics spikes as they struggle to handle requests. Alternatively, the Redis instance on node-6 might be having disk I/O issues because of the background saving, which could slow down services that depend on it, like cartservice.\\n\\nAnother angle is container network issues. Since multiple service instances are showing high network receive metrics, maybe there's a problem with packet loss or retransmission in the containers. But looking at the alerts, I don't see specific indicators of packet loss or corruption, just increased receive metrics. So maybe it's more about the load on the node causing network congestion.\\n\\nWait, the node-5 CPU and I/O metrics are both up. So perhaps the node itself is overloaded, which affects all services running on it. That would explain why multiple services have network receive spikes\\u2014they're all trying to communicate, but the node can't handle the load, causing delays or increased network usage.\\n\\nAlso, the Redis logs don't show errors, but if the save was large, it might have caused temporary I/O spikes on node-6 where Redis is hosted. However, the main issue seems to be more related to node-5's resource usage.\\n\\nPutting it together, the top three root causes could be:\\n\\n1. Node CPU load on node-5 causing service instances to misbehave.\\n2. Node disk I/O on node-5 due to high write operations affecting services.\\n3. Container network packet loss in one of the service instances leading to increased network metrics.\\n\\nI need to check if these fit the fault types. Node CPU load is type 10, node disk write I/O is 14, and container packet loss is type 6. Each of these could explain the symptoms through different propagation paths.\\n\\nFor the first, node-5's high CPU would affect all services hosted there, leading to their network metrics spiking as they can't process requests efficiently.\\n\\nThe second, high disk I/O on node-5, would slow down services trying to read or write data, leading to delayed responses and increased network receive metrics as the system tries to catch up.\\n\\nThe third, if a container like cartservice-1 has packet loss, it would cause retransmissions, increasing the network receive metrics for that container, and potentially affecting dependent services.\\n\\nSo, I think these three are the most likely, with node-5's CPU being the top suspect because it's a broader issue affecting multiple services.\\n</think>\\n\\nHere is the structured presentation of the three most likely root cause faults, ranked in order of likelihood:\\n\\n---\\n\\n### 1. **Node CPU Load**\\n- **Type**: Node CPU load (10)\\n- **Description**: High CPU usage on node-5 causing performance degradation for hosted services.\\n- **Location**: node-5 (Host)\\n- **Justification**: The alert at 08:42:00 shows a spike in system.cpu.pct_usage for node-5, indicating high CPU load. This node hosts multiple service instances (cartservice2-0, checkoutservice-2, shippingservice-2, adservice-2) which could be affected by resource contention, leading to increased network receive metrics observed in their respective services.\\n- **Propagation Path**: node-5 --(hosts)--> cartservice2-0 --(instance_of)--> cartservice; node-5 --(hosts)--> checkoutservice-2 --(instance_of)--> checkoutservice; node-5 --(hosts)--> shippingservice-2 --(instance_of)--> shippingservice; node-5 --(hosts)--> adservice-2 --(instance_of)--> adservice.\\n\\n---\\n\\n### 2. **Node Disk Write I/O Consumption**\\n- **Type**: Node disk write I/O consumption (14)\\n- **Description**: High disk write operations on node-5 affecting service performance.\\n- **Location**: node-5 (Host)\\n- **Justification**: The alert at 08:48:00 indicates high system.io.w_s (write operations) on node-5. This could slow down disk operations for services hosted on this node, leading to delayed responses and increased network metrics as services struggle to handle data writes efficiently.\\n- **Propagation Path**: node-5 --(hosts)--> cartservice2-0 --(instance_of)--> cartservice; node-5 --(hosts)--> checkoutservice-2 --(instance_of)--> checkoutservice; node-5 --(hosts)--> shippingservice-2 --(instance_of)--> shippingservice; node-5 --(hosts)--> adservice-2 --(instance_of)--> adservice.\\n\\n---\\n\\n### 3. **Container Network Packet Loss**\\n- **Type**: Container network packet loss (6)\\n- **Description**: Packet loss in a service instance causing increased network receive metrics.\\n- **Location**: cartservice-1 (Service_Instance)\\n- **Justification**: The alert at 08:41:00 shows a spike in container_network_receive_MB.eth0 for cartservice-1. This could indicate packet loss leading to retransmissions and increased network traffic, affecting the service's ability to communicate efficiently.\\n- **Propagation Path**: cartservice-1 --(instance_of)--> cartservice --(data_flow)--> redis-cart --(has_instance)--> redis-cart-0; cartservice-1 --(hosted_on)--> node-6.\\n\\n---\\n\\nThese faults are ranked based on the breadth of impact and the clarity of propagation paths through the knowledge graph. {"kg_id": "Online-Boutique-cloudbed-1-KG", "fault_id": "1", "messages": "[{\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"SystemMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"You are a helpful and rigorous assistant who is an expert in root cause analysis for complex cloud-based software systems.\", \"type\": \"system\", \"id\": \"d531d020-97b2-4c94-8c38-a19df82df43d\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"HumanMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## SYSTEM OVERVIEW\\nConsider a cloud-based software system composed of multiple interconnected components (both software and hardware). Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. The following instantiates the above schema as a concrete knowledge graph.\\n\\n### Nodes\\n- checkoutservice (Service)\\n- currencyservice (Service)\\n- emailservice (Service)\\n- frontend (Service)\\n- paymentservice (Service)\\n- productcatalogservice (Service)\\n- productcatalog (Database)\\n- recommendationservice (Service)\\n- shippingservice (Service)\\n- adservice (Service)\\n- A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. {"kg_id": "Online-Boutique-cloudbed-1-KG", "fault_id": "5", "messages": "[{\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"SystemMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"You are a helpful and rigorous assistant who is an expert in root cause analysis for complex cloud-based software systems.\", \"type\": \"system\", \"id\": \"b42f577b-4671-4034-b5ce-4761294643ff\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"HumanMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## SYSTEM OVERVIEW\\nConsider a cloud-based software system composed of multiple interconnected components (both software and hardware). Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. observed alerts to identify the **three most likely root cause faults** that could explain the symptoms.\\n\\nEach fault:\\n- Must be localized to a single system component (node in the graph) of type `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- Must be restricted to the fault types listed in the INSTRUCTIONS section below\\n- Should include a plausible propagation path through the system that justifies how the fault led to the observed symptoms. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Ensure your reasoning is traceable and grounded in the knowledge graph.\", \"type\": \"human\", \"id\": \"e974b927-c466-4d95-ab40-00ff217f8dfe\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"AIMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"<think>\\nAlright, I'm trying to figure out the root cause of the symptoms observed in the system. Let me start by looking at the alerts and see what stands out.\\n\\nFirst, I notice a lot of metric alerts related to container memory usage and threads. For example, adservice-2 and emailservice-0 both have increased memory usage. Similarly, shippingservice-1 and others have higher thread counts. This makes me think there might be a memory issue somewhere, but I'm not sure where yet.\\n\\nThen, I see logs from redis-cart-0 about background saving. The logs mention that the background saving started and completed successfully, but they also note that 0 MB of memory was used by copy-on-write. That's interesting because it suggests that the Redis instance might not be under heavy load, but the saving is happening frequently. Maybe this is normal, but I should consider if it's related to the other metrics.\\n\\nLooking at the nodes, most of the service instances are hosted on node-6, while some are on node-5. The alerts for node-6 include high CPU and memory usage. For example, at 11:00:00, node-6's CPU usage is up, and memory is up too. This could indicate that node-6 is overloaded, which might be causing the issues with the services running on it.\\n\\nI also see that node-1's memory is down at 10:59:00, which is a bit confusing. Maybe node-1 isn't the main issue, but I should keep it in mind.\\n\\nNow, considering the possible faults. The high CPU on node-6 makes me think of a node CPU spike or high node CPU load. The memory issues on service instances could be due to container memory load, but if node-6 is overloaded, that might affect all services running there.\\n\\nLooking at the knowledge graph, node-6 hosts a lot of services, including adservice, cartservice, checkoutservice, etc. If node-6's CPU is spiking, it could cause these services to have higher thread usage and memory consumption. That would explain the alerts from adservice-2, emailservice-0, and others.\\n\\nAnother possibility is a container memory issue, but since multiple services on the same node are affected, it's more likely a node-level problem. The Redis logs don't show errors, so I don't think that's the root cause. However, the frequent saves might be a symptom of the node's high load.\\n\\nThe propagation path would be that the node's high CPU affects the hosted services, leading to their increased resource usage. So, node-6's CPU spike is the most likely root cause.\\n\\nNext, I see that node-5's memory is up at 11:01:00. Node-5 hosts some instances like shippingservice-2 and cartservice2-0. The alerts for these services might be due to node-5's memory consumption. So, node memory consumption on node-5 is another possible fault.\\n\\nLastly, the logs about Redis background saving and the metric alert on redis-cart-0's network receive could hint at a disk write issue. Redis saving data frequently might be causing high disk I/O, but since the logs don't show errors, it's less likely. However, if node-6's disk is heavily used, that could be a factor. But I think the CPU and memory issues are more pressing.\\n\\nSo, the top three faults I think are node CPU spike on node-6, node memory consumption on node-5, and maybe node disk write on node-6, though the latter is less certain.\\n</think>\\n\\nHere are the three most likely root cause faults based on the observed symptoms and the knowledge graph:\\n\\n---\\n\\n### **Fault 1**\\n- **Type**: Node CPU spike\\n- **Description**: The node experienced a sudden increase in CPU usage, leading to resource contention and degraded performance for hosted services.\\n- **Location**: node-6\\n- **Justification**: \\n  - Multiple services hosted on node-6 (e.g., adservice-0, cartservice-0, checkoutservice-0) show increased container memory and thread usage.\\n  - Node-6's CPU usage is directly observed to spike at 11:00:00.\\n  - High CPU usage can cause cascading effects such as increased memory usage and slower I/O operations, explaining the correlated metrics.\\n- **Propagation Path**: `checkoutservice-0 --(hosted_on)--> node-6 --(hosts)--> adservice-0`\\n\\n---\\n\\n### **Fault 2**\\n- **Type**: Node memory consumption\\n- **Description**: The node experienced abnormally high memory usage, potentially causing memory pressure for hosted services.\\n- **Location**: node-5\\n- **Justification**: \\n  - Node-5's memory usage is observed to increase at 11:01:00.\\n  - Services hosted on node-5 (e.g., shippingservice-2, cartservice2-0) show anomalous behavior, such as increased container memory usage and network activity.\\n  - High memory usage can lead to resource contention and degraded performance for services running on the node.\\n- **Propagation Path**: `shippingservice-2 --(hosted_on)--> node-5 --(hosts)--> cartservice2-0`\\n\\n---\\n\\n### **Fault 3**\\n- **Type**: Node disk write I/O consumption\\n- **Description**: The node experienced high disk write I/O consumption, potentially causing delays in write operations for hosted services.\\n- **Location**: node-6\\n- **Justification**: \\n  - A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Let's start by going through the alerts and the knowledge graph to see where the issues might be coming from.\\n\\nFirst, looking at the metric alerts from 11:20:00.000, there are several services and hosts showing anomalies. For example, adservice-2, emailservice-0, node-5, and others have metrics like memory usage and CPU usage going up or down. This suggests that multiple components are experiencing stress, which could indicate a widespread issue or a problem in a shared resource.\\n\\nThe logs from redis-cart-0 around 11:23:51.000 show background saving started and completed successfully, but the fact that it's happening might indicate that the Redis instance is handling a lot of data, possibly leading to I/O issues. Since Redis is used for caching, if it's saving data frequently, it might be causing delays or increased I/O load on its host.\\n\\nLooking at the knowledge graph, I see that many services are hosted on node-6 and node-5. For instance, node-6 hosts adservice-0, adservice-1, etc., while node-5 hosts some instances of shippingservice, cartservice, and others. The fact that both nodes are showing high CPU and memory usage (node-5's system.mem.used is up) suggests that these hosts might be overloaded.\\n\\nNext, considering the service instances, adservice-2 is hosted on node-5 and has high memory usage. Similarly, shippingservice-1 on node-6 is showing high CPU and memory. These could be individual instances with issues, but since their metrics are up, it's more likely that their host nodes are struggling, causing the instances to perform poorly.\\n\\nThe propagation paths are important here. For example, if node-5 is experiencing high memory consumption, all services hosted there (like adservice-2, cartservice2-0, checkoutservice-2) would be affected. Similarly, node-6 hosting many services might be the common point where the issue starts, affecting all its hosted instances.\\n\\nThe logs from Redis also point towards possible I/O issues. If Redis is saving data frequently, it could be due to high write operations, which might be causing node-6's disk to have high write I/O consumption. This would slow down Redis and any services depending on it, like cartservice, which has a data flow to redis-cart.\\n\\nPutting this together, the most likely root causes are:\\n\\n1. Node-5 has high memory consumption, affecting all services hosted there.\\n2. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. container_network_receive_MB.eth0 | up\\n\\n## TASK\\nUse the knowledge graph and the observed alerts to identify the **three most likely root cause faults** that could explain the symptoms.\\n\\nEach fault:\\n- Must be localized to a single system component (node in the graph) of type `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- Must be restricted to the fault types listed in the INSTRUCTIONS section below\\n- Should include a plausible propagation path through the system that justifies how the fault led to the observed symptoms. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Ensure your reasoning is traceable and grounded in the knowledge graph.\", \"type\": \"human\", \"id\": \"6baeb629-b067-4d96-ade9-0cf07f9462fc\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"AIMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"<think>\\nAlright, I'm trying to figure out the root cause of the symptoms observed in the cloud-based software system. Let's start by looking at the provided information.\\n\\nFirst, I notice that the symptoms are mostly logs and metric alerts from various services. The logs from recommendationservice instances show errors like `socket.gaierror: [Errno -2] Name or service not known` and `Temporary failure in name resolution`. These errors suggest DNS resolution issues or connectivity problems. The metric alerts indicate that some container memory usages are down, which might mean those containers are either not running or under heavy load.\\n\\nLooking at the knowledge graph, I see that recommendationservice has multiple instances (recommendationservice-0, -1, -2) all hosted on node-6. The logs from these instances are showing repeated connection issues, which points to a possible problem with node-6 itself, as all instances are on the same host.\\n\\nNext, the metric alerts show that some services like currencyservice and paymentservice have container memory usage down. This could mean those services are experiencing issues, but since the logs don't show errors from them, it's less likely they're the root cause. Instead, their issues might be a result of something else failing.\\n\\nThe frontend services are also showing errors with request disconnects, which could be because they're trying to connect to the recommendationservice and failing, thus propagating the issue. The frontend is connected to recommendationservice via control flow edges, so a failure there would directly impact the frontend.\\n\\nConsidering the propagation paths, if node-6 is having network issues, all services hosted there (like recommendationservice, frontend, etc.) would be affected. The DNS errors could be due to node-6's network configuration or a problem with the node's ability to resolve hostnames.\\n\\nSo, putting it together, the most likely root cause is a node-level network latency on node-6. This would explain why all recommendationservice instances on that node are failing to resolve hostnames and connect, leading to the observed errors. The frontend, which depends on recommendationservice, then shows errors because it can't connect, and other services might have secondary effects due to the overall system stress.\\n\\nAnother possible fault is a service-level issue with recommendationservice itself, where all instances are misconfigured. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. This could propagate to dependent services causing them to have reduced memory, hence the down alerts.\\n\\n2. **Container Network Latency or Packet Loss**: Increased network receive metrics could indicate higher traffic, but without specific latency or loss metrics, it's less clear. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. {"kg_id": "Online-Boutique-cloudbed-1-KG", "fault_id": "10", "messages": "[{\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"SystemMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"You are a helpful and rigorous assistant who is an expert in root cause analysis for complex cloud-based software systems.\", \"type\": \"system\", \"id\": \"5bfc21b7-e75e-41e5-aafe-cdd16bd7fd85\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"HumanMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## SYSTEM OVERVIEW\\nConsider a cloud-based software system composed of multiple interconnected components (both software and hardware). Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. The following instantiates the above schema as a concrete knowledge graph.\\n\\n### Nodes\\n- checkoutservice (Service)\\n- currencyservice (Service)\\n- emailservice (Service)\\n- frontend (Service)\\n- paymentservice (Service)\\n- productcatalogservice (Service)\\n- productcatalog (Database)\\n- recommendationservice (Service)\\n- shippingservice (Service)\\n- adservice (Service)\\n- There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. {"kg_id": "Online-Boutique-cloudbed-1-KG", "fault_id": "11", "messages": "[{\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"SystemMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"You are a helpful and rigorous assistant who is an expert in root cause analysis for complex cloud-based software systems.\", \"type\": \"system\", \"id\": \"0bfab701-bbc4-4d23-935c-b7e26185ea5c\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"HumanMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## SYSTEM OVERVIEW\\nConsider a cloud-based software system composed of multiple interconnected components (both software and hardware). Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Ensure your reasoning is traceable and grounded in the knowledge graph.\", \"type\": \"human\", \"id\": \"d6c50df5-6a3b-4818-802f-bdd2a6d9ec65\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"AIMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"<think>\\nAlright, I'm trying to figure out the root causes for the observed symptoms in this cloud-based system. Let me start by going through the information provided.\\n\\nFirst, I see that there are multiple services and their instances, each hosted on various nodes. The symptoms include both metric and log alerts. The metric alerts show various container and node-level issues like high CPU usage, memory usage, network metrics, and disk operations. The logs from redis-cart-0 indicate a background saving process, which could be related to disk I/O.\\n\\nI'll focus on the logs first because they often give clear indicators. The logs from redis-cart-0 show that a background save started, saved data, and completed successfully. However, the RDB shows 0 MB used by copy-on-write, which might indicate some issue with memory or disk during the save process. Since Redis is used for caching, any issues here could affect services that rely on it, like the cartservice.\\n\\nLooking at the metric alerts, I notice that several services have high CPU and memory usage. For example, adservice-2, cartservice-1, checkoutservice-2, etc., all show increased container_memory_usage_MB or container_cpu_usage_seconds. This suggests that these services might be experiencing some resource contention or increased load.\\n\\nI also see node-level metrics, like node-4's high CPU and memory usage. If a node is overloaded, all services hosted on it could suffer performance degradation. Checking the hosting information, node-6 hosts a lot of service instances, including redis-cart-0. High disk usage on node-6 could explain the Redis save issues and the high I/O metrics in shippingservice-2.\\n\\nPutting this together, the most likely root causes are:\\n\\n1. **Node Disk Write I/O Load on node-6**: The Redis logs and the shippingservice-2's high disk reads suggest that node-6 is experiencing heavy disk write operations. This could be slowing down Redis saves and causing cascading effects on services that depend on Redis, like cartservice.\\n\\n2. **Container Memory Load on cartservice-1**: The high memory usage here could indicate a memory leak or increased load, causing this instance to struggle, which then affects the cartservice's functionality and its communication with Redis.\\n\\n3. **Node CPU Spike on node-4**: High CPU usage on node-4 might be causing services hosted there to perform poorly. However, since node-4 isn't hosting as many critical services as node-6, this might be a secondary issue.\\n\\nI think the node-level disk issue is the primary culprit because it directly impacts Redis, which is a critical cache for carts. The container memory issue in cartservice-1 is also significant because it's a symptom that could be both a cause and an effect of the node's disk problem. The node CPU spike, while important, seems less directly connected to the majority of the alerts observed.\\n</think>\\n\\n## Step-by-Step Explanation and Answer\\n\\n### Identified Root Causes and Justification\\n\\n#### 1. Node Disk Write I/O Consumption on node-6\\n- **Type**: Node disk write I/O consumption\\n- **Description**: High disk write operations on node-6, potentially causing slow I/O and affecting services relying on disk operations.\\n- **Location**: node-6 (Host)\\n- **Justification**: Logs from redis-cart-0 show a background save operation, which involves disk writes. Additionally, shippingservice-2 on node-5 shows high disk reads, but node-6's role as host for redis-cart-0 and many services suggests it's a central point for disk activity. The high write I/O could slow down Redis operations, leading to cascading effects on dependent services.\\n- **Propagation Path**: redis-cart --(has_instance)--> redis-cart-0 --(hosted_on)--> node-6. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. TASK\\nUse the knowledge graph and the observed alerts to identify the **three most likely root cause faults** that could explain the symptoms.\\n\\nEach fault:\\n- Must be localized to a single system component (node in the graph) of type `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- Must be restricted to the fault types listed in the INSTRUCTIONS section below\\n- Should include a plausible propagation path through the system that justifies how the fault led to the observed symptoms. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step.
